docs.lead_paragraph: Previewing the themes for her re-election drive next year, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is opening an effort emphasizing her role on defense and other areas that Republicans have long used to their advantage. On a Web site that is to go into operation on Wednesday, Hillary for Senate (www.hillaryclinton.com), Mrs. Clinton's re-election campaign, also highlights her goal of reducing abortions by preventing unwanted pregnancies, even as it casts her as a champion of abortion rights.

headline.main: In Cyberspace, A New Effort To Broaden Clinton Appeal

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, July 11 - Previewing the themes for her re-election drive next year, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is opening an effort emphasizing her role on defense and other areas that Republicans have long used to their advantage....

docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton appears to have decided to run for Senate again. Presumably, she has been persuaded that a 2006 re-election campaign will not harm her possible bid for the presidency in 2008. But some Democrats, including me, think she shouldn't run for re-election. A Clinton senatorial campaign is likely to be the most bruising and high-stakes race of 2006. The Republicans will put everything they have into attacking Mrs. Clinton, knowing that whatever damage they can inflict will pay dividends for them in 2008.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by CNBC commentator and Democratic strategist Hilary Rosen on why Sen Hillary Clinton should focus on 2008 presidential race instead of running for re-election (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The perpetuation of overindulgence in summer camp is unfortunate. (Soapbox: ''Sending Candy to Campers? Shhh!'' Aug. 4.) I feel sorry for the children of parents who feel the need to maintain that kind of control over their children at summer camp and who need to spoil those children in absentia. Sleep-away camp is an opportunity for kids to learn to live in a cohesive group setting, to let the needs of the group supercede individual wants and to get outside some of the conspicuous consumption of their home environments.
docs.abstract: Hillary Brizell-Deiise letter on August 4 Soapbox essay scores parents who break rules about candy and other forbidden items at sleep-away camps

headline.main: Going to Camp Means Respecting Rules

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In the column, Mr. Redburn mentioned academic research suggesting that being surrounded by intelligent, motivated students offers a great advantage. As a student who transferred from the University of Colorado at Boulder to an Ivy League school -- Cornell -- I am evidence of this fact.
docs.abstract: Hillary Profeta letter comments on Tom Redburn's April 21 Economic View column on deliberations carried out by teenage daughter in deciding which college to attend

docs.lead_paragraph: A relatively new strategy to raise soft money for Senate campaigns, one used to great effect last year by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, would be banned under the campaign finance bill passed Monday by the United States Senate. But New York State's own porous campaign finance laws would remain unaffected by the bill, sponsored by Senators John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Russell D. Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin. The state parties would still be allowed to collect soft-money contributions of unlimited size and use the money to help candidates in state races. In fact, most campaign finance experts predict that McCain-Feingold will have little effect on New York politics and its culture of aggressive fund-raising.
docs.abstract: Article contends that relatively new strategy to raise soft money for Senate campaigns, one used to great effect last year by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, would be banned under campaign finance bill passed by United States Senate but New York's own porous campaign finance laws would remain unaffected (M)

headline.main: New York Politics Would Be Largely Immune Under Campaign Finance Measure

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is understandably pleased by the approval she received on Wednesday from the Senate Ethics Committee for her $8 million deal to sell her memoirs. In finding that the transaction passes muster under the Senate's rules governing book deals, the committee essentially supported Mrs. Clinton's contention that both her auction of the book to the highest bidder and the terms governing her advance payments conformed to ''usual and customary'' publishing practice, the Senate's standard for assessing members' book agreements. According to a statement issued by her lawyer, Robert Barnett, Mrs. Clinton has already received one-third of the $8 million advance. Under the terms of the contract, the remaining payments will be spread out over the next several years, presumably timed to coincide with various milestones toward the manuscript's completion. Regrettably, Mrs. Clinton still declines to reveal the full details of her contract or to release her submission to the committee.
docs.abstract: Editorial says finding that Sen Hillary Rodham Clinton's book deal with Simon & Schuster conforms to Senate's standard for assessing members' book agreements does not make it any less inappropriate; says Senate should adopt House standards, which restrict members' payments to royalties on books actually sold (M)
docs.snippet: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is understandably pleased by the approval she received on Wednesday from the Senate Ethics Committee for her $8 million deal to sell her memoirs. In finding that the transaction passes muster under the Senate's rules...

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator-elect Hillary Rodham Clinton agreed last night to sell Simon & Schuster a memoir of her years as first lady, for the near-record advance of about $8 million. The deal ends a frantic weeklong bidding war that provoked widespread curiosity about just what she planned to write. Mrs. Clinton had told publishers she planned to discuss her feelings about the scandals of her husband's administration as well as her thoughts about women's changing roles in the world.
docs.abstract: New York Senator-elect Hillary Rodham Clinton agrees to sell Simon & Schuster memoir of her years as First Lady; advance on royalties is $8 million, portion of which will be donated to charity; book is scheduled for publication in 2003; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE she goes again! First, the health care debacle, with full credit due Hillary Rodham Clinton, who failed to get the changes she wanted because she acted as if public debate should follow rather than precede her prescriptions.
docs.abstract: Joyce Purnick Metro Matters column discusses New York Senator-Elect Hillary Rodham Clinton's statement that she will co-sponsor legislation to abolish Electoral College; suggests Clinton should be more circumspect before announcing her solution; Purnick holds that Electoral College protects minorities and forces candidates to pay attention to African-Americans, Jews, Hispanics and union workers who form larger proportion of electorate in large states than they do nationally; exaggerates influence of states with small populations; contends issue is larger than Clinton suggests and politically daunting, requiring debate and careful analysis (M)

headline.main: Metro Matters; Cart Before Horse Trading Just Won't Do

docs.lead_paragraph: It is the lowest, meanest, nastiest insult one Georgia politician can hurl at another. It is worse than scalawag or Yankee, liberal or atheist, so incendiary a weapon that it has not been wheeled out until the final weeks of the campaign. But now, even small children can turn on the television around Atlanta and hear two Republicans liken their opponents to . . . Hillary!
docs.abstract: Republicans in Georgia campaigning for Congress liken their Democratic opponents to Hillary Rodham Clinton, which is considered nastiest insult one Georgia politician can hurl at another; especially at risk are Democrats who are seeking seats in regions where they are not native, just as Hillary Clinton is seeking Senate seat from New York (M)

headline.main: For Georgia Name-Calling, Nothing Is Lower Than 'Hillary'

docs.lead_paragraph: A chart yesterday tracing Hillary Rodham Clinton's approval ratings in opinion polls over the last eight years referred incorrectly in some copies to the sources of the data. They were 40 national and 6 statewide polls, not 46 national and 6 statewide.
